content.description: Squeeze chimney all the way. Climb all the way into the wide crack at the bottom to the back of the crack where you start to head up. Work your way up the chimney to get first piece of pro way in the back of the crack. I felt the crux of this pitch was getting out of the top where the back of the crack is broken rock providing only marginal protection and having to work your way toward the front of the crack if you are larger to exit. The second pitch is more squeeze chimney. Protection is found in horizontal and vertical crack, but like the first pitch, it runs out towards to top.
content.protection: A standard rack. There are bolted anchors at the top of both pitches.
content.location: This is the farthest right climb as far as I know.

content.description: Not a whole lot to describe here as just looking at the route gives you all the information.  Most climbs can be done in one pitch, but make it two to avoid rope drag on the course rock.  Easy start to the ledge then the crux, off camber crack.  Continue left and up as the crack goes to the top.... walk off.  My rating is based on the climbs here and not that of others in it's grade.

After that two hour drive, you're ready to climb, so you bag the first route you see (if you followed the directions).  Cabin Fever is a good warm up for the day here.  Short, a little intense.....  A bit tricky to set a top rope, best done on lead.

Wrap your hands for this one, as the first section hurts.  Climb to the ledge for the first belay.  The next section goes at 5.9 and opens up as you get higher.  Stop after pitch two and walk off or add a third, short pitch of 5.7.
